dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So Alibaba, their IPO, this is like, the biggest IPO ever, right? Like, globally?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Alibaba, their I P O, this is like, the biggest I P O ever, right? Like, globally?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debut on the Hong Kong stock exchange is a secondary listing for Alibaba, which initially went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014, raising $25 billion in the worlds biggest IPO in history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, wait, actually no! Not ever. It's the biggest this year, though.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would also be the worlds biggest IPO so far in 2019: Alibabas Hong Kong listing exceeds Ubers $8.1 billion public debut in New York and AB InBevs $5 billion IPO of its Asia business in Hong Kong earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for 2019! Yes, exactly! I knew that. My bad.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but still huge, right? Like, $13.5 billion in Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The price means that Alibaba is set to raise at least $11.3 billion, and up to $12.9 billion if a greenshoe option to list more shares is exercised

dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, that's insane. And it's a secondary listing, too. After their New York debut.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, that's insane. And it's a secondary listing, too. After their New York debut.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debut on the Hong Kong stock exchange is a secondary listing for Alibaba, which initially went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014, raising $25 billion in the worlds biggest IPO in history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And they had to close the books early, because demand was just, uh, through the roof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And they had to close the books early, because demand was just, uh, through the roof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the skyrocketing demand for shares caused Alibaba to close its books earlier than expected, according to CNBC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! People just want in. And this is like, solidifying Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! People just want in. And this is like, solidifying Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will help boost Hong Kongs financial markets...Alibabas listing helps cement the Hong Kong Stock Exchange as one of this years largest venues for IPOs

dialogue_turns.text: Totally! Especially with, you know, everything going on there. It's a huge vote of confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! Especially with, you know, everything going on there. It's a huge vote of confidence.

dialogue_turns.text: It's like, "We still believe in Hong Kong!" even with the, uh, recession.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like, We still believe in Hong Kong! even with the, uh, recession.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will help boost Hong Kongs financial markets, given that the city recently slid into recession for the first time in over a decade, following more than five months of anti-government protests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. And their cash reserves are gonna be, like, $46 billion. No other internet company even comes close.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. And their cash reserves are gonna be, like, forty six dollars billion. No other internet company even comes close.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Scheduled for November 26, the listing could swell Alibabas cash pile to around $44 billion, which would be more than any other internet company and double that of rival e-commerce giant Tencent, according to Bloomberg.

dialogue_turns.text: Forty-six billion? That's more than Tencent!

dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! It's wild. But get this, it's gonna be topped.

dialogue_turns.text: And don't even get me started on Singles Day. $40.1 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And don't even get me started on Singles Day. forty point one dollars billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In its eleventh edition of Singles Day, the biggest shopping event in the world, Alibaba set a new sales record of $38.4 billion in gross merchandise volume during the 24-hour shopping bonanza.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's literally more than Black Friday, Cyber Monday, and Prime Day combined.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's literally more than Black Friday, Cyber Monday, and Prime Day combined.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To compare, Singles Day far outpaces other big e-commerce days in the U.S., with Alibabas haul more than double the amount sold on last years Black Friday, Cyber Monday and Amazon Prime Day combined.
